27.37: Man to man reserveth anger, and doth he seek remedy of God?
27.38: He hath no mercy on a man like himself, and doth he entreat for his own sins?
27.39: He that is but flesh, nourisheth anger, and doth he ask forgiveness of God? who shall obtain pardon for his sins?
27.40: Remember thy last things, and let enmity cease:
27.41: For corruption and death hang over in his commandments.
27.42: Remember the fear of God, and be not angry with thy neighbour.
27.43: Remember the covenant of the most High, and overlook the ignorance of thy neighbour.
27.44: Refrain from strife, and thou shalt diminish thy sins:
27.45: For a passionate man kindleth strife, and a sinful man will trouble his friends, and bring in debate in the midst of them that are at peace.
27.46: For as the wood of the forest is, so the fire burneth: and as a man's strength is, so shall his anger be, and according to his riches he shall increase his anger.
27.47: A hasty contention kindleth a fire: and a hasty quarrel sheddeth blood: and a tongue that beareth witness bringeth death.
27.48: If thou blow the spark, it shall burn as a fire: and if thou spit upon it, it shall be quenched: both come out of the mouth.
27.49: The whisperer and the double-tongued is accursed: for he hath troubled many that were at peace.
27.50: The tongue of a third person hath disquieted many, and scattered them from nation to nation.
27.51: It hath destroyed the strong cities of the rich, and hath overthrown the houses of great men.
27.52: It hath cut in pieces the forces of people, and undone strong nations.
27.53: The tongue of a third person hath cast out valiant women, and deprived them of their labours.
27.54: He that hearkeneth to it, shall never have rest, neither shall he have a friend in whom he may repose.
27.55: The stroke of a whip maketh a blue mark: but the stroke of the tongue will break the bones.
27.56: Many have fallen by the edge of the sword, but not so many as have perished by their own tongue.
27.57: Blessed is he that is defended from a wicked tongue, that hath not passed into the wrath thereof, and that hath not drawn the yoke thereof, and hath not been bound in its bands.
27.58: For its yoke is a yoke of iron: and its bands are bands of brass.
27.59: The death thereof is a most evil death: and hell is preferable to it.
27.60: Its continuance shall not be for a long time, but it shall possess the ways of the unjust: and the just shall not be burnt with its flame.
27.61: They that forsake God shall fall into it, and it shall burn in them, and shall not be quenched, and it shall be sent upon them as a lion, and as a leopard it shall tear them.
27.62: Hedge in thy ears with horns, hear not a wicked tongue, and make doors and bars to thy mouth.
27.63: Melt down thy gold and silver, and make a balance for thy words, and a just bridle for thy mouth:
27.64: And take heed lest thou slip with thy tongue, and fall in the sight of thy enemies who lie in wait for thee, and thy fall be incurable unto death.

28.1: He that sheweth mercy, lendeth to his neighbour: and he that is stronger in hand keepeth the commandments.
28.2: Lend to thy neighbour in the time of his need, and pay thou thy neighbour again in due time.
28.3: Keep thy word, and deal faithfully with him: and thou shalt always find that which is necessary for thee.
28.4: Many have looked upon a thing lent as a thing found, and have given trouble to them that helped them.
28.5: Till they receive, they kiss the hands of the lender, and in promises they humble their voice:
28.6: But when they should repay, they will ask time, and will return tedious and murmuring words, and will complain of the time:
28.7: And if he be able to pay, he will stand off, he will scarce pay one half, and will count it as if he had found it.
28.8: But if not, he will defraud him of his money, and he shall get him for an enemy without cause:
28.9: And he will pay him with reproaches and curses, and instead of honour and good turn will repay him injuries.
28.10: Many have refused to lend, not out of wickedness, but they were afraid to be defrauded without cause.
28.11: But yet towards the poor be thou more hearty, and delay not to shew him mercy.
28.12: Help the poor because of the commandment: and send him not away empty-handed because of his poverty.
28.13: Lose thy money for thy brother and thy friend: and hide it not under a stone to be lost.
28.14: *Place thy treasure in the commandments of the most High, and it shall bring thee more profit than gold.
28.15: Shut up alms in the heart of the poor, and it shall obtain help for thee against all evil.
28.16: Better than the shield of the mighty, and better than the spear:
28.17: It shall fight for thee against thy enemy.
28.18: A good man is surety for his neighbour: and he that hath lost shame, will leave him to himself.
28.19: Forget not the kindness of thy surety: for he hath given his life for thee.
28.20: The sinner and the unclean fleeth from his surety.
28.21: A sinner attributeth to himself the goods of his surety: and he that is of an unthankful mind will leave him that delivered him.
28.22: A man is surety for his neighbour: and when he hath lost all shame, he shall forsake him.
28.23: Evil suretyship hath undone many of good estate, and hath tossed them as a wave of the sea.
28.24: It hath made powerful men to go from place to place round about, and they have wandered in strange countries.
28.25: A sinner that transgresseth the commandment of the Lord shall fall into an evil suretyship: and he that undertaketh many things shall fall into judgment.
28.26: Recover thy neighbour according to thy power, and take heed to thyself that thou fall not.
28.27: The chief thing for man's life is water and bread, and clothing, and a house to cover shame.
28.28: *Better is the poor man's fare under a roof of boards, than sumptuous cheer abroad in another man's house.
28.29: Be contented with little instead of much, and thou shalt not hear the reproach of going abroad.
28.30: It is a miserable life to go as a guest from house to house: for where a man is a stranger, he shall not deal confidently, nor open his mouth.
28.31: He shall entertain, and feed, and give drink to the unthankful, and moreover he shall hear bitter words.
28.32: Go, stranger, and furnish the table, and give others to eat what thou hast in thy hand.
28.33: Give place to the honourable presence of my friends: for I want my house, my brother being to be lodged with me.
28.34: These things are grievous to a man of understanding: the upbraiding of house-room, and the reproaching of the lender.

29.1: He *that loveth his son, frequently chastiseth him, that he may rejoice in his latter end, and not grope after the doors of his neighbours.
29.2: He that instructeth his son shall be praised in him, and shall glory in him in the midst of them of his household.
29.3: *He that teacheth his son, maketh his enemy jealous, and in the midst of his friends he shall glory in him.
29.4: His father is dead, and he is as if he were not dead: for he hath left one behind him that is like himself.
29.5: While he lived he saw and rejoiced in him: and when he died he was not sorrowful, neither was he confounded before his enemies.
29.6: For he left behind him a defender of his house against his enemies, and one that will requite kindness to his friends.
29.7: For the souls of his sons he shall bind up his wounds, and at every cry his bowels shall be troubled.
29.8: A horse not broken becometh stubborn, and a child left to himself will become headstrong.
29.9: Give thy son his way, and he shall make thee afraid: play with him, and he shall make thee sorrowful.
29.10: Laugh not with him, lest thou have sorrow, and at the last thy teeth be set on edge.
29.11: Give him not liberty in his youth, and wink not at his devices.
29.12: *Bow down his neck while he is young, and beat his sides while he is a child, lest he grow stubborn, and regard thee not, and so be a sorrow of heart to thee.
29.13: Instruct thy son, and labour about him, lest his lewd behaviour be an offence to thee.
29.14: Better is a poor man who is sound, and strong of constitution, than a rich man who is weak, and afflicted with evils.
29.15: Health of the soul in holiness of justice, is better then all gold and silver: and a sound body, than immense revenues.
29.16: There is no riches above the riches of the health of the body: and there is no pleasure above the joy of the heart.
29.17: Better is death than a bitter life: and everlasting rest, than continual sickness.
29.18: Good things that are hidden in a mouth that is shut, are as messes of meat set about a grave.
29.19: *What good shall an offering do to an idol? for it can neither eat, nor smell:
29.20: So is he that is persecuted by the Lord, bearing the reward of his iniquity:
29.21: *He seeth with his eyes, and groaneth, as an eunuch embracing a virgin, and sighing.
29.22: *Give not up thy soul to sadness, and afflict not thyself in thy own counsel.
29.23: The joyfulness of the heart, is the life of a man, and a never failing treasure of holiness: and the joy of a man is length of life.
29.24: Have pity on thy own soul, pleasing God, and contain thyself: gather up thy heart in his holiness: and drive away sadness far from thee.
29.25: *For sadness hath killed many, and there is no profit in it.
29.26: Envy and anger shorten a man's days, and pensiveness will bring old age before the time.
29.27: A cheerful and good heart is always feasting: for his banquets are prepared with diligence.

30.1: Watching for riches consumeth the flesh, and the thought thereof driveth away sleep.
30.2: The thinking beforehand turneth away the understanding, and a grievous sickness maketh the soul sober.
30.3: The rich man hath laboured in gathering riches together, and when he resteth he shall be filled with his goods.
30.4: The poor man hath laboured in his low way of life, and in the end he is still poor.
30.5: He that loveth gold, shall not be justified: and he that followeth after corruption, shall be filled with it.
30.6: *Many have been brought to fall for gold, and the beauty thereof hath been their ruin.
30.7: Gold is a stumbling-block to them that sacrifice to it: woe to them that eagerly follow after it, and every fool shall perish by it.
30.8: Blessed is the rich man that is found without blemish: and that hath not gone after gold, nor put his trust in money nor in treasures.
30.9: Who is he, and we will praise him? for he hath done wonderful things in his life.
30.10: Who hath been tried thereby, and made perfect, he shall have glory everlasting. He that could have transgressed, and hath not transgressed: and could do evil things, and hath not done them:
30.11: Therefore are his goods established in the Lord, and all the church of the saints shall declare his alms.
30.12: Art thou set at a great table? be not the first to open thy mouth upon it.
30.13: Say not: There are many things which are upon it.
30.14: Remember that a wicked eye is evil.
30.15: What is created more wicked than an eye? therefore shall it weep over all the face when it shall see.
30.16: Stretch not out thy hand first, lest being disgraced with envy thou be put to confusion.
30.17: Be not hasty in a feast.
30.18: Judge of the disposition of thy neighbour by thyself.
30.19: Use as a frugal man the things that are set before thee: lest if thou eatest much, thou be hated.
30.20: Leave off first, for manners sake: and exceed not, lest thou offend.
30.21: And if thou sittest among many, reach not thy hand out first of all: and be not the first to ask for drink.
30.22: How sufficient is a little wine for a man well taught, and in sleeping thou shalt not be uneasy with it, and thou shalt feel no pain.
30.23: Watching, and choler, and gripes, are with an intemperate man:
30.24: Sound and wholesome sleep with a moderate man: he shall sleep till morning, and his soul shall be delighted with him.
30.25: And if thou hast been forced to eat much, arise, go out, and vomit: and it shall refresh thee, and thou shalt not bring sickness upon thy body.
30.26: Hear me, my son, and despise me not: and in the end thou shalt find my words.
30.27: In all thy works be quick, and no infirmity shall come to thee.
30.28: The lips of many shall bless him that is liberal of his bread, and the testimony of his truth is faithful.
30.29: Against him that is niggardly of his bread, the city will murmur, and the testimony of his niggardliness is true.
30.30: Challenge not them that love wine: *for wine hath destroyed very many.
30.31: Fire trieth hard iron: so wine drunk to excess shall rebuke the hearts of the proud.
30.32: Wine taken with sobriety is equal life to men: if thou drink it moderately, thou shalt be sober.
30.33: What is his life, who is diminished with wine?
30.35: *Wine was created from the beginning to make men joyful, and not to make them drunk.
30.36: Wine drunken with moderation is the joy of the soul, and the heart.
30.37: Sober drinking is health to soul and body.
30.38: Wine drunken with excess raiseth quarrels, and wrath, and many ruins.
30.39: Wine drunken with excess is bitterness of the soul.
30.40: The heat of drunkenness is the stumbling-block of the fool, lessening strength, and causing wounds.
30.41: Rebuke not thy neighbour in a banquet of wine: and despise him not in his mirth.
30.42: Speak not to him words of reproach: and press him not in demanding again.

31.30: No evils shall happen to him that feareth the Lord, but in temptation God will keep him, and deliver him from evils.
31.31: A wise man hateth not the commandments and justices, and he shall not be dashed in pieces as a ship in a storm.
31.32: A man of understanding is faithful to the law of God, and the law is faithful to him.
31.33: He that cleareth up a question, shall prepare what to say, and so having prayed he shall be heard, and shall keep discipline, and then he shall answer.
31.34: *The heart of a fool is as a wheel of a cart: and his thoughts are like a rolling axle-tree.
31.35: A friend that is a mocker, is like a stallion horse: he neigheth under every one that sitteth upon him.
31.36: Why doth one day excel another, and one light another, and one year another year, when all come of the sun?
31.37: By the knowledge of the Lord they were distinguished, the sun being made, and keeping his commandment.
31.38: And he ordered the seasons, and holidays of them, and in them they celebrated festivals at an hour.
31.39: Some of them God made high and great days, and some of them he put in the number of ordinary days. And all men are from the ground, *and out of the earth, from whence Adam was created.
31.40: With much knowledge the Lord hath divided them, and diversified their ways.
31.41: Some of them hath he blessed, and exalted: and some of them hath he sanctified, and set near himself: and some of them hath he cursed and brought low, and turned them from their station.
31.42: *As the potter's clay is in his hand, to fashion and order it.
31.43: All his ways are according to his ordering: so man is in the hand of him that made him, and he will render to him according to his judgment.
31.44: Good is set against evil, and life against death: so also is the sinner against a just man. And so look upon all the works of the most High. Two and two, and one against another.
31.45: And I awaked last of all, and as one that gathereth after the grape-gatherers.
31.46: In the blessing of God I also have hoped: and as one that gathereth grapes, have I filled the wine-press.
31.47: *See that I have not laboured for myself only, but for all that seek discipline.
31.48: Hear me, ye great men, and all ye people, and hearken with your ears, ye rulers of the church.
31.49: Give not to son or wife, brother or friend, power over thee while thou livest; and give not thy estate to another: lest thou repent, and thou entreat for the same.
31.50: As long as thou livest, and hast breath in thee, let no man change thee.
31.51: For it is better that thy children should ask of thee, than that thou look toward the hands of thy children.
31.52: In all thy works keep the pre-eminence.
31.53: Let no stain sully thy glory. In the time when thou shalt end the days of thy life, and in the time of thy decease, distribute thy inheritance.
31.54: Fodder, and a wand, and a burden, are for an ass: bread, and correction, and work, for a slave.
31.55: He worketh under correction, and seeketh to rest: let his hands be idle, and he seeketh liberty.
31.56: The yoke and the thong bend a stiff neck, and continual labours bow a slave.
31.57: Torture and fetters are for a malicious slave: send him to work, that he be not idle:
31.58: For idleness hath taught much evil.
31.59: Set him to work: for so it is fit for him. And if he be not obedient, bring him down with fetters, but be not excessive towards any one: and do no grievous thing without judgment.
31.60: *If thou have a faithful servant, let him be to thee as thy own soul: treat him as a brother: because in the blood of thy soul thou hast gotten him.
31.61: If thou hurt him unjustly, he will run away:
31.62: And if he rise up and depart, thou knowest not whom to ask, and in what way to seek him.

32.1: The hopes of a man that is void of understanding are vain and deceitful: and dreams lift up fools.
32.2: The man that giveth heed to lying visions, is like to him that catcheth at a shadow, and followeth after the wind.
32.3: The vision of dreams is the resemblance of one thing to another: as when a man's likeness is before the face of a man.
32.4: What can be made clean by the unclean? and what truth can come from that which is false?
32.5: Deceitful divinations and lying omens, and the dreams of evil doers, are vanity:
32.6: And the heart fancieth as that of a woman in travail: except it be a vision sent forth from the Most High, set no thy heart upon them.
32.7: For dreams have deceived many, and they have failed that put their trust in them.
32.8: The word of the law shall be fulfilled without a lie, and wisdom shall be made plain in the mouth of the faithful.
32.9: What doth he know, that hath not been tried? A man that hath much experience, shall think of many things: and he that hath learned many things, shall shew forth understanding.
32.10: He that hath no experience, knoweth little: and he that hath been experienced in many things, multiplieth prudence.
32.11: He that hath not been tried, what manner of things doth he know? he that hath been surprised, shall abound with subtlety.
32.12: I have seen many things by travelling, and many customs of things.
32.13: Sometimes I have been in danger of death for these things, and I have been delivered by the grace of God.
32.14: The spirit of those that fear God, is sought after, and by his regard shall be blessed.
32.15: For their hope is on him that saveth them, and the eyes of God are upon them that love him.
32.16: He that feareth the Lord shall tremble at nothing, and shall not be afraid: for he is his hope.
32.17: The soul of him that feareth the Lord is blessed.
32.18: To whom doth he look, and who is his strength?
32.19: *The eyes of the Lord are upon them that fear him, he is their powerful protector, and strong stay, a defence from the heat, and a cover from the sun at noon.
32.20: A preservation from stumbling, and a help from falling; he raiseth up the soul, and enlighteneth the eyes, and giving health, and life, and blessing.
32.21: *The offering of him that sacrificeth of a thing wrongfully gotten, is stained; and the mockeries of the unjust are not acceptable.  The Lord is only for them that wait upon him in the way of truth and justice.
32.22: *The Most High approveth not the gifts of the wicked: neither hath he respect to the oblations of the unjust, nor will he be pacified for sins by the multitude of their sacrifices.
32.23: He that offereth sacrifice of the goods of the poor, is as one that sacrificeth the son in the presence of his father.
32.24: The bread of the needy is the life of the poor: he that defraudeth them thereof, is a man of blood.
32.25: He that taketh away the bread gotten by sweat, is like him that killeth his neighbour.
32.26: He that sheddeth blood, *and he that defraudeth the labourer of his hire, are brothers.
32.27: When one buildeth up, and another pulleth down: what profit have they but the labour?
32.28: When one prayeth, and another curseth: whose voice will God hear?
32.29: He that washeth himself after touching the dead, if he toucheth him again, what doth his washing avail?
32.30: *So a man that fasteth for his sins, and doth the same again, what doth his humbling himself profit him? who will hear his prayer?

33.1: He that keepeth the law, multiplieth offerings.
33.2: *It is a wholesome sacrifice to take heed to the commandments, and to depart from all iniquity.
33.3: And to depart from injustice, is to offer a propitiatory sacrifice for injustices, and a begging of pardon for sins.
33.4: He shall return thanks that offereth fine flour: and he that doth mercy offereth sacrifice.
33.5: *To depart from iniquity, is that which pleaseth the Lord, and to depart from injustice, is an entreaty for sins.
33.6: *Thou shalt not appear empty in the sight of the Lord.
33.7: For all these things are to be done, because of the commandment of God.
33.8: The oblation of the just maketh the altar fat, and is an odour of sweetness in the sight of the Most High.
33.9: The sacrifice of the just is acceptable, and the Lord will not forget the memorial thereof.
33.10: Give glory to God with a good heart: and diminish not the first-fruits of thy hands.
33.11: *In every gift shew a cheerful countenance, and sanctify thy tithes with joy.
33.12: Give to the Most High according to what he hath given to thee, and with a good eye do according to the ability of thy hands:
33.13: For the Lord maketh recompense, and will give thee seven times as much.
33.14: *Do not offer wicked gifts, for such he will not receive.
33.15: And look not upon an unjust sacrifice, for the Lord is judge, *and there is not with him respect of person.
33.16: The Lord will not accept any person against a poor man, and he will hear the prayer of him that is wronged.
33.17: He will not despise the prayers of the fatherless: nor the widow, when she poureth out her complaint.
33.18: Do not the widow's tears run down the cheek, and her cry against him that causeth them to fall?
33.19: For from the cheek they go up even to heaven, and the Lord that heareth will not be delighted with them.
33.20: He that adoreth God with joy, shall be accepted, and his prayer shall approach even to the clouds.
33.21: The prayer of him that humbleth himself shall pierce the clouds: and till it come nigh he will not be comforted: and he will not depart till the Most High behold.
33.22: And the Lord will not be slack, but will judge for the just, and will do judgment: and the Almighty will not have patience with them, that he may crush their back:
33.23: And he will repay vengeance to the Gentiles, till he have taken away the multitude of the proud, and broken the sceptres of the unjust,
33.24: Till he have rendered to men according to their deeds: and according to the works of Adam, and according to his presumption.
33.25: Till he have judged the cause of his people, and he shall delight the just with his mercy.
33.26: The mercy of God is beautiful in the time of affliction, as a cloud of rain in the time of drought.

34.1: Have mercy upon us, O God of all, and behold us, and shew us the light of thy mercies:
34.2: And send thy fear upon the nations, that have not sought after thee: that they may know that there is no God beside thee, and that they may shew forth thy wonders.
34.3: Lift up thy hand over the strange nations, that they may see thy power.
34.4: For as thou hast been sanctified in us in their sight, so thou shalt be magnified among them in our presence,
34.5: That they may know thee, as we also have known thee, that there is no God beside thee, O Lord.
34.6: Renew thy signs, and work new miracles.
34.7: Glorify thy hand, and thy right arm.
34.8: Raise up indignation, and pour out wrath.
34.9: Take away the adversary, and crush the enemy.
34.10: Hasten the time, and remember the end, that they may declare thy wonderful works.
34.11: Let him that escapeth be consumed by the rage of the fire: and let them perish that oppress thy people.
34.12: Crush the head of the princes of the enemies, that say: There is no other beside us.
34.13: Gather together all the tribes of Jacob: that they may know that there is no God besides thee, and may declare thy great works: and thou shalt inherit them as from the beginning.
34.14: Have mercy on thy people, upon whom thy name is invoked: and upon Israel, *whom thou hast raised up to be thy first-born.
34.15: Have mercy on Jerusalem, the city which thou hast sanctified, the city of thy rest.
34.16: Fill Sion with thy unspeakable words, and thy people with thy glory.
34.17: Give testimony to them that are thy creatures from the beginning, and raise up the prophecies which the former prophets spoke in thy name.
34.18: Reward them that patiently wait for thee, that thy prophets may be found faithful: and hear the prayers of thy servants,
34.19: *According to the blessing of Aaron over thy people, and direct us into the way of justice, and let all know that dwell upon the earth, that thou art God, the beholder of all ages.
34.20: The belly will devour all meat, yet one is better than another.
34.21: The palate tasteth venison, and the wise heart false speeches.
34.22: A perverse heart will cause grief, and a man of experience will resist it.
34.23: A woman will receive every man: yet one daughter is better than another.
34.24: The beauty of a woman cheereth the countenance of her husband, and a man desireth nothing more.
34.25: If she have a tongue that can cure, and likewise mitigate and shew mercy: her husband is not like other men.
34.26: He that possesseth a good wife, beginneth a possession: she is a help like to himself, and a pillar of rest.
34.27: Where there is no hedge, the possession shall be spoiled: and where there is no wife, he mourneth that is in want.
34.28: Who will trust him that hath no rest, and that lodgeth wheresoever the night taketh him, as a robber well appointed, that skippeth from city to city.

35.36: Honour the physician for the need thou hast of him: for the Most High hath created him.
35.37: For all healing is from God, and he shall receive gifts of the king.
35.38: The skill of the physician shall lift up his head, and in the sight of great men he shall be praised.
35.39: The Most High hath created medicines out of the earth, and a wise man will not abhor them.
35.40: *Was not bitter water made sweet with wood?
35.41: The virtue of these things is come to the knowledge of men, and the Most High hath given knowledge to men, that he may be honoured in his wonders.
35.42: By these he shall cure and shall allay their pains, and of these the apothecary shall make sweet confections, and shall make up ointments of health, and of his works there shall be no end.
35.43: For the peace of God is over all the face of the earth.
35.44: *My son, in thy sickness neglect not thyself, but pray to the Lord, and he shall heal thee.
35.45: Turn away from sin, and order thy hands aright, and cleanse thy heart from all offence.
35.46: Give a sweet savour, and a memorial of fine flour, and make a fat offering, and then give place to the physician.
35.47: For the Lord created him: and let him not depart from thee, for his works are necessary.
35.48: For there is a time when thou must fall into their hands:
35.49: And they shall beseech the Lord, that he would prosper what they give for ease and remedy, for their conversation.
35.50: He that sinneth in the sight of his Maker, shall fall into the hands of the physician.
35.51: My son, shed tears over the dead, and begin to lament as if thou hadst suffered some great harm, and according to judgment cover his body, and neglect not his burial.
35.52: And for fear of being ill spoken of, weep bitterly for a day, and then comfort thyself in thy sadness.
35.53: And make mourning for him according to his merit, for a day or two, for fear of detraction.
35.54: *For of sadness cometh death, and it overwhelmeth the strength, and the sorrow of the heart boweth down the neck.
35.55: In withdrawing aside, sorrow remaineth: and the substance of the poor is according to his heart.
35.56: Give not up thy heart to sadness, but drive it from thee: and remember the latter end.
35.57: Forget it not: for there is no returning, and thou shalt do him no good, and shalt hurt thyself.
35.58: Remember my judgment: for thine also shall be so: yesterday for me, and to-day for thee.
35.59: *When the dead is at rest, let his remembrance rest, and comfort him in the departing of his spirit.
35.60: The wisdom of a scribe cometh by his time of leisure: and he that is less in action, shall receive wisdom.
35.61: With what wisdom shall he be furnished that holdeth the plough, and that glorieth in the goad, that driveth the oxen therewith, and is occupied in their labours, and his whole talk is about the offspring of bulls?
35.62: He shall give his mind to turn up furrows, and his care is to give the kine fodder.
35.63: So every craftsman and workmaster that laboureth night and day, he who maketh graven seals, and by his continual diligence varieth the figure: he shall give his mind to the resemblance of the picture, and by his watching shall finish the work.
35.64: So doth the smith sitting by the anvil, and considering the iron-work. The vapour of the fire wasteth his flesh, and he fighteth with the heat of the furnace:
35.65: The noise of the hammer is always in his ears, and his eye is upon the pattern of the vessel he maketh.
35.66: He setteth his mind to finish his work, and his watching to polish them to perfection.
35.67: So doth the potter sitting at his work, turning the wheel about with his feet, who is always carefully set to his work, and maketh all his work by number:
35.68: He fashioneth the clay with his arm, and boweth down his strength before his feet.
35.69: He shall give his mind to finish the glazing, and his watching to make clean the furnace.
35.70: All these trust to their hands, and every one is wise in his own art.
35.71: Without these a city is not built.
35.72: And they shall not dwell nor walk about therein, and they shall not go up into the assembly.
35.73: Upon the judges' seat they shall not sit, and the ordinance of judgment they shall not understand, neither shall they declare discipline and judgment, and they shall not be found where parables are spoken:
35.74: But they shall strengthen the state of the world, and their prayer shall be in the work of their craft, applying their soul, and searching in the law of the Most High.

36.1: The wise men will seek out the wisdom of all the ancients, and will be occupied in the prophets.
36.2: He will keep the sayings of renowned men, and will enter withal into the subtilties of parables.
36.3: He will search out the hidden meanings of proverbs, and will be conversant in the secrets of parables.
36.4: He shall serve among great men, and: appear before the governor.
36.5: He shall pass into strange countries: for he shall try good and evil among men:
36.6: He will give his heart to resort early to the Lord, that made him, and he will pray in the sight of the Most High.
36.7: He will open his mouth in prayer, and will make supplication for his sins.
36.8: For if it shall please the great Lord, he will fill him with the spirit of understanding:
36.9: And he will pour forth the words of his wisdom as showers, and in his prayer he will confess to the Lord.
36.10: And he shall direct his counsel, and his knowledge, and in his secrets shall he meditate.
36.11: He shall shew forth the discipline he hath learned, and shall glory in the law of the covenant of the Lord.
36.12: Many shall praise his wisdom, and it shall never be forgotten.
36.13: The memory of him shall not depart away, and his name shall be in request from generation to generation.
36.14: Nations shall declare his wisdom, and the church shall shew forth his praise.
36.15: If he continue, he shall leave a name above a thousand: and if he rest, it shall be to his advantage.
36.16: I will yet meditate, that I may declare: for I am filled as with a holy transport.
36.17: By a voice he saith: Hear me, ye divine offspring, and bud forth as the rose planted by the brooks of waters.
36.18: Give ye a sweet odour as frankincense.
36.19: Send forth flowers, as the lily, and yield a smell, and bring forth leaves in grace, and praise with canticles, and bless the Lord in his works.
36.20: Magnify his name, and give glory to him with the voice of your lips, and with the canticles of your mouths, and with harps: and in praising him, you shall say in this manner:
36.21: *All the works of the Lord are exceeding good.
36.22: *At his word the waters stood as a heap: and at the words of his mouth the receptacles of waters:
36.23: For at his commandment favour is shewn, and there is no diminishing of his salvation.
36.24: The works of all flesh are before him, and there is nothing hid from his eyes.
36.25: He seeth from eternity to eternity, and there is nothing wonderful before him.
36.26: There is no saying: What is this, or what is that? for all things shall be sought in their time.
36.27: His blessing hath overflowed like a river:
36.28: *And as a flood hath watered the earth; so shall his wrath inherit the nations that have not sought after him:
36.29: *Even as he turned the waters into a dry land, and the earth was made dry: and his ways were made plain for their journey: so to sinners they are stumbling-blocks in his wrath.
36.30: Good things were created for the good from the beginning; so for the wicked, good and evil things.
36.31: *The principal things necessary for the life of men, are: water, fire, and iron, salt, milk, and bread of flour, and honey, and the cluster of the grape, and oil, and clothing.
36.32: All these things shall be for good to the holy; so to the sinners, and the ungodly, they shall be turned into evil.
36.33: There are spirits that are created for vengeance, and in their fury they lay on grievous torments:
36.34: In the time of destruction they shall pour out their force: and they shall appease the wrath of him that made them.
36.35: Fire, hail, famine, and death: all these were created for vengeance.
36.36: The teeth of beasts, and scorpions, and serpents, and the sword taking vengeance upon the ungodly unto destruction.
36.37: In his commandments they shall feast, and they shall be ready upon earth when need is, and when their time is come, they shall not transgress his word.
36.38: Therefore, from the beginning I was resolved, and I have meditated and thought on these things, and left them in writing.
36.39: *All the works of the Lord are good, and he will furnish every work in due time.
36.40: It is not to be said: This is worse than that: for all shall be well approved in their time.
36.41: Now, therefore, with the whole heart and mouth praise ye him, and bless the name of the Lord.

37.1: Great labour is created for all men, and a heavy yoke is upon the children of Adam, from the day of their coming out of their mother's womb, until the day of their burial into the mother of all.
37.2: Their thoughts, and fears of the heart, their imagination of things to come, and the day of their end:
37.3: From him that sitteth on a glorious throne, unto him that is humbled in earth and ashes:
37.4: From him that weareth purple, and beareth the crown, even to him that is covered with rough linen: wrath, envy, trouble, unquietness, and the fear of death, continual anger and strife,
37.5: And in the time of rest upon his bed, the sleep of the night changeth his knowledge.
37.6: A little and as nothing is his rest, and afterward in sleep, as in the day of keeping watch.
37.7: He is troubled in the vision of his heart, as if he had escaped in the day of battle. In the time of his safety he rose up, and wondereth that there is no fear:
37.8: Such things happen to all flesh, from man even to beast, and upon sinners are sevenfold more.
37.9: *Moreover, death and bloodshed, strife and sword, oppressions, famine, and affliction, and scourges:
37.10: All these things are created for the wicked, *and for their sakes came the flood.
37.11: *All things that are of the earth shall return to the earth again, **and all waters shall return to the sea.
37.12: All bribery and injustice shall blotted out, and fidelity shall stand for ever.
37.13: The riches of the unjust shall be dried up like a river, and shall pass away a noise like a great thunder in rain.
37.14: While he openeth his hands, he shall rejoice: but transgressors shall pine away in the end.
37.15: The offspring of the ungodly shall not bring forth many branches, and make a noise as unclean roots upon the top of a rock.
37.16: The weed growing over every water, and at the bank of the river, shall be pulled up before all grass.
37.17: Grace is like a paradise in blessings, and mercy remaineth for ever.
37.18: The life of a labourer, that is content with what he hath, shall be sweet, and in it thou shalt find a treasure.
37.19: Children, and the building of a city, shall establish a name; but a blameless wife shall be counted above them both.
37.20: Wine and music rejoice the heart: but the love of wisdom is above them both.
37.21: The flute and the psaltery make a sweet melody, but a pleasant tongue is above them both.
37.22: Thy eye desireth favour and beauty, but more than these green sown fields.
37.23: A friend and companion meeting together, in season; but above them both, is a wife with her husband.
37.24: Brethren are a help in the time of trouble, but mercy shall deliver more than they.
37.25: Gold and silver make the feet stand sure: but wise counsel is above them both.
37.26: Riches and strength lift up the heart, but above these is the fear of the Lord.
37.27: There is no want in the fear of the Lord, and it needeth not to seek for help.
37.28: The fear of the Lord is like a paradise of blessing, and they have covered it above all glory.
37.29: My son, in thy life-time be not indigent; for it is better to die than to want.
37.30: The life of him that looketh toward another man's table, is not to be counted a life: for he feedeth his soul with another man's meat.
37.31: But a man, well instructed and taught, will look to himself.
37.32: Begging will be sweet in the mouth of the unwise, but in his belly there shall burn a fire.

38.1: O death, how bitter is the remembrance of thee to a man that hath peace in his possessions!
38.2: To a man that is at rest, and whose ways are prosperous in all things, and that is yet able to take meat!
38.3: O death, thy sentence is welcome to the man that is in need, and to him whose strength faileth:
38.4: Who is in a decrepit age, and that is in care about all things: and to the distrustful that loseth patience!
38.5: Fear not the sentence of death. Remember what things have been before thee, and what shall come after thee: this sentence is from the Lord upon all flesh.
38.6: And what shall come upon thee by the good pleasure of the Most High? whether ten, or a hundred, or a thousand years.
38.7: For among the dead there is no accusing of life.
38.8: The children of sinners become children of abominations, and they that converse near the houses of the ungodly.
38.9: The inheritance of the children of sinners shall perish, and with their posterity shall be a perpetual reproach.
38.10: The children will complain of an ungodly father, because for his sake they are a reproach.
38.11: Woe to you, ungodly men, who have forsaken the law of the most high Lord.
38.12: And if you be born, you shall be born in malediction: and if you die, in malediction shall be your portion.
38.13: *All things that are of the earth, shall return into the earth: so the ungodly shall from malediction to destruction.
38.14: The mourning of men is about their body, but the name of the ungodly shall be blotted out.
38.15: Take care of a good name: for this shall continue with thee more than a thousand treasures, precious and great.
38.16: A good life hath its number of days: but a good name shall continue for ever.
38.17: My children, keep discipline in peace: *for wisdom that is hid, and a treasure that is not seen, what profit is there in them both?
38.18: Better is the man that hideth his folly, than the man that hideth his wisdom.
38.19: Wherefore, have a shame of these things I am now going to speak of.
38.20: For it is not good to keep all shamefacedness, and all things do not please all men, in opinion.
38.21: Be ashamed of fornication before father and mother; and of a lie before a governor and a man in power;
38.22: Of an offence before a prince and a judge; of iniquity before a congregation and a people;
38.23: Of injustice before a companion and friend: And in regard to the place where thou dwellest,
38.24: Of theft, and of the truth of God, and the covenant; of leaning with thy elbow over meat, and of deceit in giving and taking;
38.25: Of silence before them that salute thee; of looking upon a harlot; and of turning away thy face from thy kinsman.
38.26: Turn not sway thy face from thy neighbour; and of taking away a portion, and not restoring.
38.27: *Gaze not upon another man's wife, and be not inquisitive after his handmaid, and approach not her bed.
38.28: Be ashamed of upbraiding speeches before friends; and after thou hast given, upbraid not.

39.1: Repeat not the word which thou hast heard, and disclose not the thing that is secret; so shalt thou be truly without confusion, and shall find favour before all men: be not ashamed of any of these things, *and accept no person to sin thereby.
39.2: Of the law of the Most High, and of his covenant, and of judgment to justify the ungodly.
39.3: Of the affair of companions and travellers, and of the gift of the inheritance of friends.
39.4: Of exactness of balance and weights, of getting much or little.
39.5: Of the corruption of buying, and of merchants, and of much correction of children, and to make the side of a wicked slave to bleed.
39.6: Sure keeping is good over a wicked wife.
39.7: Where there are many hands, shut up, and deliver all things in number and weight; and put all in writing that thou givest out or receivest in.
39.8: Be not ashamed to inform the unwise and foolish, and the aged, that are judged by young men: and thou shalt be well instructed in all things, and well approved in the sight of all men living.
39.9: The father waketh for the daughter when no man knoweth, and the care for her taketh away his sleep, when she is young, lest she pass away the flower of her age, and when she is married lest she should be hateful:
39.10: In her virginity, lest she should be corrupted, and be found with child in her father's house; and having a husband, lest she should misbehave herself, or at the least become barren.
39.11: Keep a sure watch over a shameless daughter; lest at any time she make thee become a laughing-stock to thy enemies, and a bye-word in the city, and a reproach among the people, and she make thee ashamed before all the multitude.
39.12: Behold not every body's beauty: and tarry not among women.
39.13: For from garments cometh a moth, and from a woman the iniquity of a man.
39.14: For better is the iniquity of a man, than a woman doing a good turn, and a woman bringing shame and reproach.
39.15: I will now remember the works of the Lord, and I will declare the things I have seen. By the words of the Lord are his works.
39.16: The sun giving light hath looked upon all things, and full of the glory of the Lord is his work.
39.17: Hath not the Lord made the saints to declare all his wonderful works, which the Lord Almighty hath firmly settled to be established for his glory?
39.18: He hath searched out the deep, and the heart of men, and considered their crafty devices.
39.19: For the Lord knoweth all knowledge, and hath beheld the signs of the world, he declareth the things that are past, and the things that are to come, and revealeth the traces of hidden things.
39.20: No thought escapeth him, and no word can hide itself from him.
39.21: He hath beautified the glorious works of his wisdom: and he is from eternity to eternity, and to him nothing may be added,
39.22: Nor can he be diminished, and he hath no need of any counsellor.
39.23: O how desirable are all his works, and what we can know is but as a spark!
39.24: All these things live and remain for ever, and for every use all things obey him.
39.25: All things are double, one against another, and he hath made nothing defective.
39.26: He hath established the good things of every one. And who shall be filled with beholding his glory?

40.1: The firmament on high is his beauty, the beauty of heaven with its glorious shew.
40.2: The sun, when he appeareth shewing forth at his rising, an admirable instrument, the work of the Most High.
40.3: At noon he burneth the earth; and who can abide his burning heat? As one keeping a furnace in works of heat:
40.4: The sun three times as much, burneth the mountains, breathing out fiery vapours, and shining with his beams, he blindeth the eyes.
40.5: Great is the Lord that made him, and at his words he hath hastened his course.
40.6: And the moon in all in her season, is for a declaration of times and a sign of the world.
40.7: From the moon is the sign of the festival-day, a light that decreaseth in her perfection.
40.8: The month is called after her name, increasing wonderfully in her perfection.
40.9: Being an instrument of the armies on high, shining gloriously in the firmament of heaven.
40.10: The glory of the stars is the beauty of heaven; the Lord enlighteneth the world on high.
40.11: By the words of the holy one they shall stand in judgment, and shall never fail in their watches.
40.12: Look upon the rainbow, and bless him that made it: *it is very beautiful in its brightness.
40.13: It encompasseth the heaven about with the circle of its glory, the hands of the Most High have displayed it.
40.14: By his commandment he maketh the snow to fall apace, and sendeth forth swiftly the lightnings of his judgment.
40.15: Through this are the treasures opened, and the clouds fly out like birds.
40.16: By his greatness he hath fixed the clouds, and the hailstones are broken.
40.17: At his sight shall the mountains be shaken, and at his will the south wind shall blow.
40.18: The noise of his thunder shall strike the earth, so doth the northern storm, and the whirlwind:
40.19: And as the birds lighting upon the earth, he scattereth snow, and the falling thereof is as the coming down of locusts.
40.20: The eye admireth at the beauty of the whiteness thereof, and the heart is astonished at the shower thereof.
40.21: He shall pour frost as salt upon the earth: and when it freezeth, it shall become like the tops of thistles.
40.22: The cold north wind bloweth, and the water is congealed into crystal: upon every gathering together of waters it shall rest, and shall clothe the waters as a breastplate.
40.23: And it shall devour the mountains, and burn the wilderness, and consume all that is green as with fire.
40.24: A present remedy of all is the speedy coming of a cloud, and a dew that meeteth it, by the heat that cometh, shall overpower it.
40.25: At his word the wind is still, and with his thought he appeaseth the deep, and the Lord hath planted islands therein.
40.26: Let them that sail on the sea, tell the dangers thereof: and when we hear with our ears, we shall admire.
40.27: There are great and wonderful works: a variety of beasts, and of all living things, and the monstrous creatures of whales.
40.28: Through him is established the end of their journey, and by his word all things are regulated.
40.29: We shall say much, and yet shall want words: but the sum of our words is, He is all.
40.30: What shall we be able to do to glorify him: for the Almighty himself is above all his works.
40.31: The Lord is terrible, and exceeding great, and his power is admirable.
40.32: Glorify the Lord as much as ever you can, for he will yet far exceed, and his magnificence is wonderful.
40.33: Blessing the Lord, exalt him as much as you can: for he is above all praise.
40.34: When you exalt him, put forth all your strength, and be not weary: for you can never go far enough.
40.35: *Who shall see him, and declare him? and who shall magnify him as he is from the beginning?
40.36: There are many things hidden from us that are greater than these: for we have seen but a few of his works.
40.37: But the Lord hath made all things, and to the godly he hath given wisdom.

41.1: Let us now praise men of renown, and our fathers in their generation.
41.2: The Lord hath wrought great glory through his magnificence, from the beginning.
41.3: Such as have borne rule in their dominions, men of great power, and endued with their wisdom, shewing forth in the prophets the dignity of prophets,
41.4: And ruling over the present people, and by the strength of wisdom instructing the people in most holy words.
41.5: Such as by their skill sought out musical tunes, and published canticles of the scriptures.
41.6: Rich men in virtue, studying beautifulness: living at peace in their houses.
41.7: All these have gained glory in their generations, and were praised in their days.
41.8: They that were born of them have left a name behind them, that their praises might be related:
41.9: And there are some, of whom there is no memorial: who are perished, as if they had never been: and are born, as if they had never been born, and their children with them.
41.10: But these were men of mercy, whose godly deeds have not failed:
41.11: Good things continue with their seed,
41.12: Their posterity are a holy inheritance, and their seed hath stood in the covenants:
41.13: And their children for their sakes remain for ever: their seed and their glory shall not be forsaken.
41.14: Their bodies are buried in peace, and their name liveth unto generation and generation.
41.15: Let the people shew forth their wisdom, and the church declare their praise.
41.16: *Henoch pleased God, and was translated into paradise, that he may give repentance to the nations.
41.17: *Noe was found perfect, just, and in the time of wrath he was made a reconciliation.
41.18: Therefore was there a remnant left to the earth, when the flood came.
41.19: *The covenants of the world were made with him, that all flesh should no more be destroyed with the flood.
41.20: *Abraham was the great father of a multitude of nations, and there was not found the like to him in glory, who kept the law of the Most High, and was in covenant with him.
41.21: *In his flesh he established the covenant, **and in temptation he was found faithful.
41.22: Therefore, by an oath he gave him glory in his posterity, that he should increase as the dust of the earth,
41.23: And that he would exalt his seed as the stars, and they should inherit from sea to sea, and from the river to the ends of the earth.
41.24: And he did in like manner with Isaac, for the sake of Abraham, his father.
41.25: The Lord gave him the blessing of all nations, and confirmed his covenant upon the head of Jacob.
41.26: He acknowledged him in his blessings, and gave him an inheritance, and divided him his portion in twelve tribes.
41.27: And he preserved for him men of mercy, that found grace in the eyes of all flesh.

42.1: Moses *was beloved of God, and men: whose memory is in benediction.
42.2: He made him like the saints in glory, and magnified him in the fear of his enemies, and with his words he made prodigies to cease.
42.3: *He glorified him in the sight of kings, and gave him commandments in the sight of his people, and shewed him his glory.
42.4: *He sanctified him in his faith, and meekness, and chose him out of all flesh.
42.5: For he heard him, and his voice, and brought him into a cloud.
42.6: And he gave him commandments before his face, and a law of life and instruction, that he might teach Jacob his covenant, and Israel his judgments.
42.7: He exalted Aaron, his brother, and like to himself of the tribe of Levi:
42.8: He made an everlasting covenant with him, and gave him the priesthood of the nation, and made him blessed in glory,
42.9: And he girded him about with a glorious girdle, and clothed him with a robe of glory, and crowned him with majestic attire.
42.10: He put upon him a garment to the feet, and breeches, and an ephod, and he compassed him with many little bells of gold all round about,
42.11: *That as he went there might be a sound, and a noise made that might be heard in the temple, for a memorial to the children of his people.
42.12: He gave him a holy robe of gold, and blue, and purple, a woven work, of a wise man, endued with judgment and truth:
42.13: Of twisted scarlet, the work of an artist, with precious stones cut and set in gold, and graven by the work of a lapidary, for a memorial, according to the number of the tribes of Israel.
42.14: And a crown of gold upon his mitre, wherein was engraved Holiness, an ornament of honour: a work of power, and delightful to the eyes for its beauty.
42.15: Before him there were none so beautiful, even from the beginning.
42.16: No stranger was ever clothed with them, but only his children alone, and his grand-children for ever.
42.17: His sacrifices were consumed with fire every day.
42.18: *Moses filled his hands, and anointed him with holy oil.
42.19: This was made to him for an everlasting testament, and to his seed as the days of heaven, to execute the office of the priesthood, and to have praise, and to glorify his people in his name.
42.20: He chose him out of all men living, to offer sacrifice to God, incense, and a good savour, for a memorial to make reconciliation for his people:
42.21: And he gave him power in his commandments, in the covenants of his judgments, that he should teach Jacob his testimonies, and give light to Israel in his law.
42.22: *And strangers stood up against him, and through envy, the men that were with Dathan and Abiron, compassed him about in the wilderness, and the congregation of Core, in their wrath.
42.23: The Lord God saw, and it pleased him not, and they were consumed in his wrathful indignation.
42.24: He wrought wonders upon them, and consumed them with a flame of fire.
42.25: And he added glory to Aaron, and gave him an inheritance, and divided unto him the first-fruits of the increase of the earth.
42.26: He prepared them bread in the first place unto fulness: for the sacrifices also of the Lord they shall eat, which he gave to him, and to his seed.
42.27: But he shall not inherit among the people in the land, and he hath no portion among the people: for he himself is his portion and inheritance.
42.28: *Phinees, the son of Eleazar, is the third in glory, by imitating him in the fear of the Lord:
42.29: And he stood up in the shameful fall of the people: in the goodness and readiness of his soul, he appeased God for Israel.
42.30: Therefore he made to him a covenant of peace, to be the prince of the sanctuary, and of his people, that the dignity of priesthood should be to him and to his seed for ever.
42.31: And a covenant to David, the king, the son of Jesse, of the tribe of Juda, an inheritance to him and to his seed, that he might give wisdom into our heart to judge his people in justice, that their good things might not be abolished, and he made their glory in their nation everlasting.

43.1: Valiant in war was Jesus, the son of Nave, who was successor of Moses among the prophets, who was great according to his name,
43.2: Very great for the saving the elect of God, to overthrow the enemies that rose up against them, that he might get the inheritance for Israel.
43.3: How great glory did he gain when he lifted up his hands, and stretched out swords against the cities?
43.4: Who before him hath so resisted? for the Lord himself brought the enemies.
43.5: *Was not the sun stopped in his anger, and one day made as two?
43.6: He called upon the most high Sovereign, when the enemies assaulted him on every side, and the great and holy God heard him by hailstones of exceeding great force.
43.7: He made a violent assault against the nation of his enemies, and in the descent he destroyed the adversaries,
43.8: That the nations might know his power, that it is not easy to fight against God. And he followed the mighty one:
43.9: *And in the days of Moses he did a work of mercy, he and Caleb, the son of Jephone, in standing against the enemy, and withholding the people from sins, and appeasing the wicked murmuring.
43.10: And they two being appointed, were delivered out of the danger, from among the number of six hundred thousand men on foot, to bring them into their inheritance, into the land that floweth with milk and honey.
43.11: And the Lord gave strength also to Caleb, and his strength continued even to his old age, so that he went up to the high places of the land, and his seed obtained it for an inheritance:
43.12: That all the children of Israel might see, that it is good to obey the holy God.
43.13: Then all the judges, every one by name, whose heart was not corrupted: who turned not away from the Lord,
43.14: That their memory might be blessed, and their bones spring up out of their place,
43.15: And their name continue for ever, the glory of the holy men remaining unto their children.
43.16: Samuel, the prophet of the Lord, the beloved of the Lord, his God, established a new government, and anointed princes over his people.
43.17: By the law of the Lord he judged the congregation, and the God of Jacob beheld, and by his fidelity he was proved a prophet.
43.18: And he was known to be faithful in his words, because he saw the God of light:
43.19: *And called upon the name of the Lord Almighty, in fighting against the enemies who beset him on every side, when he offered a lamb without blemish.
43.20: And the Lord thundered from heaven, and with a great noise made his voice to be heard.
43.21: And he crushed the princes of the Tyrians, and all the lords of the Philistines:
43.22: *And before the time of the end of his life in the world, he protested before the Lord, and his anointed; money, or any thing else, *even to a shoe, he had not taken of any man, and no man did accuse him.
43.23: And after this he slept, *and he made known to the king, and shewed him the end of his life, and he lifted up his voice from the earth in prophecy, to blot out the wickedness of the nation.

44.1: Then Nathan, *the prophet, arose in the days of David.
44.2: And as the fat taken away from the flesh, so was David chosen from among the children of Israel.
44.3: *He played with lions as with lambs: and with bears he did in like manner as with the lambs of the flock, in his youth.
44.4: *Did not he kill the giant, and take away reproach from his people?
44.5: In lifting up his hand, with the stone in the sling, he beat down the boasting of Goliath:
44.6: For he called upon the Lord, the Almighty, and he gave strength in his right hand, to take away the mighty warrior, and to set up the horn of his nation.
44.7: *So in ten thousand did he glorify him, and praised him in the blessings of the Lord, in offering to him a crown of glory:
44.8: For he destroyed the enemies on every side, and extirpated the Philistines, the adversaries unto this day: he broke their horn for ever.
44.9: In all his works he gave thanks to the holy One, and to the Most High, with words of glory.
44.10: With his whole heart he praised the Lord, and loved God that made him: and he gave him power against his enemies.
44.11: And he set singers before the altar, and by their voices he made sweet melody.
44.12: And to the festivals he added beauty, and set in order the solemn times, even to the end of his life, that they should praise the holy name of the Lord, and magnify the holiness of God in the morning.
44.13: *The Lord took away his sins, and exalted his horn for ever: and he gave him a covenant of the kingdom, and a throne of glory in Israel.
44.14: After him arose up a wise son, and for his sake he cast down all the power of the enemies.
44.15: *Solomon reigned in days of peace, and God, brought all his enemies under him, that he might build a house in his name, and prepare a sanctuary for ever: O how wise wast thou in thy youth!
44.16: *And thou wast filled as a river with wisdom, and thy soul covered the earth.
44.17: And thou didst multiply riddles in parables: thy name went abroad to the islands far off, and thou wast beloved in thy peace.
44.18: The countries wondered at thee for thy canticles, and proverbs, and parables, and interpretations,
44.19: And at the name of the Lord God, whose surname is, God of Israel.
44.20: *Thou didst gather gold as copper, and didst multiply silver as lead,
44.21: And thou didst bow thyself to women: and by thy body thou wast brought under subjection.
44.22: Thou hast stained thy glory, and defiled thy seed, so as to bring wrath upon thy children, and to have thy folly kindled,
44.23: That thou shouldst make the kingdom to be divided, *and out of Ephraim a rebellious kingdom to rule.
44.24: But God will not leave off his mercy, and he will not destroy, nor abolish his own works, neither will he cut up by the roots the offspring of his elect: and he will not utterly take away the seed of him that loveth the Lord.
44.25: Wherefore he gave a remnant to Jacob, and to David, of the same stock.
44.26: And Solomon had an end with his fathers.
44.27: And he left behind him of his seed, the folly of the nation,
44.28: Even Roboam, that had little wisdom, who turned away the people through his counsel:
44.29: *And Jeroboam, the son of Nabat, who caused Israel to sin, and shewed Ephraim the way of sin, and their sins were multiplied exceedingly.
44.30: They removed them far away from their land.
44.31: And they sought out all iniquities, till vengeance came upon them, and put an end to all their sins.

45.1: And *Elias, the prophet, stood up, as a fire, and his word burnt like a torch.
45.2: He brought a famine upon them, and they that provoked him in their envy, were reduced to a small number, for they could not endure the commandments of the Lord.
45.3: *By the word of the Lord he shut up the heaven, and he brought down fire from heaven thrice.
45.4: Thus was Elias magnified in his wondrous works. And who can glory like to thee?
45.5: *Who raisedst up a dead man from below, from the lot of death, by the word of the Lord God.
45.6: Who broughtest down kings to destruction, and brokest easily their power in pieces, and the glorious from their bed.
45.7: Who hearest judgment in Sina, and in Horeb the judgments of vengeance.
45.8: Who anointedst kings to penance, and madest prophets successors after thee.
45.9: *Who wast taken up in a whirlwind of fire, in a chariot of fiery horses.
45.10: Who art registered in the judgments of times to appease the wrath of the Lord, *to reconcile the heart of the father to the son, and to restore the tribes of Jacob.
45.11: Blessed are they that saw thee, and were honoured with thy friendship.
45.12: For we live only in our life, but after death our name shall not be such.
45.13: *Elias was indeed covered with the whirlwind, and his spirit was filled up in Eliseus: in his days he feared not the prince, and no man was more powerful than he.
45.14: No word could overcome him, *and after death his body prophesied.
45.15: In his life he did great wonders, and in death he wrought miracles.
45.16: For all this the people repented not, neither did they depart from their sins, till they were cast out of their land, and were scattered through all the earth.
45.17: And there was left but a small people, and a prince in the house of David.
45.18: Some of these did that which pleased God: but others committed many sins.
45.19: Ezechias fortified his city, and brought in water into the midst thereof, and he digged a rock with iron, and made a well for water.
45.20: *In his days Sennacherib came up, and sent Rabsaces, and lifted up his hand against them, and he stretched out his hand against Sion, and became proud through his power.
45.21: Then their hearts and hands trembled: and they were in pain as women in travail.
45.22: And they called upon the Lord, who is merciful, and spreading their hands, they lifted them up to heaven: and the holy Lord God quickly heard their voice.
45.23: He was not mindful of their sins, neither did he deliver them up to their enemies, but he purified them by the hand of Isaias, the holy prophet.
45.24: *He overthrew the army of the Assyrians, and the angel of the Lord destroyed them.
45.25: For Ezechias did that which pleased God, and walked valiantly in the way of David, his father, which Isaias, the great prophet, and faithful in the sight of God, had commanded him.
45.26: *In his days the sun went backward, and he lengthened the king's life.
45.27: With a great spirit he saw the things that are to come to pass at last, and comforted the mourners in Sion.
45.28: He shewed what should come to pass for ever, and secret things before they came.

46.1: The *memory of Josias is like the composition of a sweet smell made by the art of a perfumer:
46.2: His remembrance shall be sweet as honey in every mouth, and as music at a banquet of wine.
46.3: He was directed by God unto the repentance of the nation, and he took away the abominations of wickedness.
46.4: And he directed his heart towards the Lord, and in the days of sinners he strengthened godliness.
46.5: Except David, and Ezechias, and Josias, all committed sin.
46.6: For the kings of Juda forsook the law of the Most High, and despised the fear of God.
46.7: So they gave their kingdom to others, and their glory to a strange nation.
46.8: *They burnt the chosen city of holiness, and made the streets thereof desolate, according to the prediction of Jeremias.
46.9: For they treated him evil, who was consecrated a prophet from his mother's womb, to overthrow, and pluck up, and destroy, and to build again, and renew.
46.10: *It was Ezechiel that saw the glorious vision, which was shewn him upon the chariot of cherubims.
46.11: For he made mention of the enemies under the figure of rain, and of doing good to them that shewed right ways.
46.12: And may the bones of the twelve prophets spring up out of their place: for they strengthened Jacob, and redeemed themselves by strong faith.
46.13: *How shall we magnify Zorobabel? for he was as a signet on the right hand:
46.14: *In like manner Jesus, the son of Josedec? who in their days built the house, and set up a holy temple to the Lord, prepared for everlasting glory.
46.15: And let Nehemias be a long time remembered, who raised up for us our walls that were cast down, and set up the gates and the bars, who rebuilt our houses.
46.16: No man was born upon earth like Henoch: for he also was taken up from the earth.
46.17: *Nor as Joseph, who was a man born prince of his brethren, the support of his family, the ruler of his brethren, the stay of the people:
46.18: And his bones were visited, and after death they prophesied.
46.19: *Seth, and Sem, obtained glory among men: and above every soul Adam in the beginning.

47.1: Simon, *the high priest, the son of Onias, who in his life propped up the house, and in his days fortified the temple.
47.2: By him also the height of the temple was founded, the double building, and the high walls of the temple.
47.3: In his days the wells of water flowed out, and they were filled as the sea above measure.
47.4: He took care of his nation, and delivered it from destruction.
47.5: He prevailed to enlarge the city, and obtained glory in his conversation with the people: and enlarged the entrance of the house, and the court.
47.6: He shone in his days as the morning star in the midst of a cloud, and as the moon at the full.
47.7: And as the sun when it shineth, so did he shine in the temple of God.
47.8: And as the rainbow giving light in the bright clouds, and as the flower of roses in the days of the spring, and as the lilies that are on the brink of the water, and as the sweet smelling frankincense in the time of summer.
47.9: As a bright fire, and frankincense burning in the fire.
47.10: As a massy vessel of gold, adorned with every precious stone.
47.11: As an olive-tree budding forth, and a cypress-tree rearing itself on high, when he put on the robe of glory, and was clothed with the perfection of power.
47.12: When he went up to the holy altar, he honoured the vesture of holiness.
47.13: And when he took the portions out of the hands of the priests, he himself stood by the altar. And about him was the ring of his brethren: and as the cedar planted in Mount Libanus,
47.14: And as branches of palm-trees, they stood round about him, and all the sons of Aaron, in their glory.
47.15: And the oblation of the Lord was in their hands, before all the congregation of Israel: and finishing his service, on the altar, to honour the offering of the Most High King,
47.16: He stretched forth his hand to make a libation, and offered of the blood of the grape.
47.17: He poured out at the foot of the altar a divine odour to the Most High Prince.
47.18: Then the sons of Aaron shouted, they sounded with beaten trumpets, and made a great noise, to be heard for a remembrance before God.
47.19: Then all the people together made haste, and fell down to the earth upon their faces, to adore the Lord, their God, and to pray to the Almighty God, the Most High.
47.20: And the singers lifted up their voices, and in the great house the sound of sweet melody was increased.
47.21: And the people in prayer besought the Lord, the Most High, until the worship of the Lord was perfected, and they had finished their office.
47.22: Then coming down, he lifted up his hands over all the congregation of the children of Israel, to give glory to God with his lips, and to glory in his name:
47.23: And he repeated his prayer, willing to shew the power of God.
47.24: And now pray ye to the God of all, who hath done great things in all the earth, who hath increased our days from our mother's womb, and hath done with us according to his mercy:
47.25: May he grant us joyfulness of heart, and that there be peace in our days in Israel for ever:
47.26: That Israel may believe that the mercy of God is with us, to deliver us in his days.
47.27: There are two nations which my soul abhorreth: and the third is no nation, which I hate:
47.28: They that sit on Mount Seir, and the Philistines, and the foolish people that dwell in Sichem.
47.29: Jesus, the son of Sirach, of Jerusalem, hath written in this book the doctrine of wisdom and instruction, who renewed wisdom from his heart.
47.30: Blessed is he that is conversant in these good things: and he that layeth them up in his heart shall be wise always.
47.31: For if he do them, he shall be strong to do all things: because the light of God guideth his steps.

48.1: A prayer of Jesus, the son of Sirach. I will give glory to thee, O Lord, O King, and I will praise thee, O God, my Saviour.
48.2: I will give glory to thy name: for thou hast been a helper and protector to me.
48.3: And hast preserved my body from destruction, from the snare of an unjust tongue, and from the lips of them that forge lies, and in the sight of them that stood by, thou hast been my helper.
48.4: And thou hast delivered me according to the multitude of the mercy of thy name, from them that did roar, prepared to devour.
48.5: Out of the hands of them that sought my life, and from the gates of afflictions, which compassed me about:
48.6: From the oppression of the flame which surrounded me, and in the midst of the fire I was not burnt.
48.7: From the depth of the belly of hell, and from an unclean tongue, and from lying words, from an unjust king, and from a slanderous tongue:
48.8: My soul shall praise the Lord even to death:
48.9: And my life was drawing near to hell beneath.
48.10: They compassed me on every side, and there was no one that would help me. I looked for the succour of men, and there was none.
48.11: I remembered thy mercy, O Lord, and thy works, which are from the beginning of the world.
48.12: How thou deliverest them that wait for thee, O Lord, and savest them out of the hands of the nations.
48.13: Thou hast exalted my dwelling-place upon the earth and I have prayed for death to pass away.
48.14: I called upon the Lord, the Father of my Lord, that he would not leave me in the day of my trouble, and in the time of the proud, without help.
48.15: I will praise thy name continually, and will praise it with thanksgiving, and my prayer was heard.
48.16: And thou hast saved me from destruction, and hast delivered me from the evil time.
48.17: Therefore, I will give thanks, and praise thee, and bless the name of the Lord.
48.18: When I was yet young, before I wandered about, I sought for wisdom openly in my prayer.
48.19: I prayed for her before the temple, and unto the very end I will seek after her, and she flourished as a grape soon ripe.
48.20: My heart delighted in her, my foot walked in the right way, from my youth up I sought after her.
48.21: I bowed down my ear a little, and received her.
48.22: I found much wisdom in myself, and I profited much therein.
48.23: To him that giveth me wisdom, will I give glory.
48.24: For I have determined to follow her: I have had a zeal for good, and shall not be confounded.
48.25: My soul hath wrestled for her, and in doing it I have been confirmed.
48.26: I stretched forth my hands on high, and I bewailed my ignorance of her.
48.27: I directed my soul to her, and in knowledge I found her.
48.28: I possessed my heart with her from the beginning: therefore I shall not be forsaken.
48.29: My entrails were troubled in seeking her: therefore shall I possess a good possession.
48.30: The Lord hath given me a tongue for my reward: and with it I will praise him.
48.31: Draw near to me, ye unlearned, and gather yourselves together into the house of discipline.
48.32: Why are ye slow? and what do you say of these things? your souls are exceedingly thirsty.
48.33: I have opened my mouth, and have spoken: buy her for yourselves without silver,
48.34: And submit your neck to the yoke, and let your soul receive discipline: for she is near at hand to be found.
48.35: Behold with your eyes how I have laboured a little, and have found much rest to myself.
48.36: Receive ye discipline as a great sum of money, and possess abundance of gold by her.
48.37: Let your soul rejoice in his mercy, and you shall not be confounded in his praise.
48.38: Work your work before the time, and he will give you your reward in his time.

1.1: The vision of Isaias, the son of Amos, which he saw concerning Juda and Jerusalem in the days of Ozias, *Joathan, Achaz, and Ezechias, kings of Juda.
1.2: Hear, O ye heavens, and give ear, O earth, for the Lord hath spoken. I have brought up children, *and exalted them, but they have despised me.
1.3: The ox knoweth his owner, and the ass his master's crib: but Israel hath not known me, and my people hath not understood.
1.4: Woe to the sinful nation, a people laden with iniquity, a wicked seed, ungracious children: they have forsaken the Lord, they have blasphemed the holy One of Israel, they are gone away backwards.
1.5: For what shall I strike you any more, you that increase transgression? the whole head is sick, and the whole heart is sad.
1.6: From the sole of the foot unto the top of the head, there is no soundness therein: wounds and bruises, and swelling sores: they are not bound up, nor dressed, nor fomented with oil.
1.7: *Your land is desolate, your cities are burnt with fire: your country strangers devour before your face, and it shall be desolate as when wasted by enemies.
1.8: And the daughter of Sion shall be left as a covert in a vineyard, and as a lodge in a garden of cucumbers, and as a city that is laid waste.
1.9: *Except the Lord of hosts had left us seed, **we had been as Sodom, and we should have been like to Gomorrha.
1.10: Hear the word of the Lord, ye rulers of Sodom, give ear to the law of our God, ye people of Gomorrha.
1.11: *To what purpose do you offer me the multitude of your victims, saith the Lord? I am full, I desire not holocausts of rams, and fat of fatlings, and blood of calves, and lambs, and buck-goats.
1.12: When you came to appear before me, who required these things at your hands, that you should walk in my courts?
1.13: Offer sacrifice no more in vain: incense is an abomination to me. The new moons, and the sabbaths, and other festivals, I will not abide, your assemblies are wicked.
1.14: My soul hateth your new moons, and your solemnities: they are become troublesome to me, I am weary of bearing them.
1.15: And when you stretch forth your hands, I will turn away my eyes from you: and when you multiply prayer, I will not hear: *for your hands are full of blood.
1.16: *Wash yourselves, be clean, take away the evil of your devices from my eyes: cease to do perversely,
1.17: Learn to do well: seek judgment, relieve the oppressed, judge for the fatherless, defend the widow.
1.18: And then come, and accuse me, saith the Lord: if your sins be as scarlet, they shall be made as white as snow: and if they be red as crimson, they shall be white as wool.
1.19: If you be willing, and will hearken to me, you shall eat the good things of the land.
1.20: But if you will not, and will provoke me to wrath: the sword shall devour you, because the mouth of the Lord hath spoken it.
1.21: How is the faithful city, that was full of judgment, become a harlot? justice dwelt in it, but now murderers.
1.22: Thy silver is turned into dross: thy wine is mingled with water.
1.23: Thy princes are faithless, companions of thieves: they all love bribes, the run after rewards. *They judge not for the fatherless: and the widow's cometh not in to them.
1.24: Therefore, saith the Lord, the God of hosts, the mighty one of Israel: Ah! I will comfort myself over my adversaries: and I will be revenged of my enemies.
1.25: And I will turn my hand to thee, and I will clean purge away thy dross, and I will take away all thy tin.
1.26: And I will restore thy judges as they were before, and thy counsellors as of old. After this thou shalt be called the city of the just, a faithful city.
1.27: Sion shall be redeemed in judgment, and they shall bring her back in justice.
1.28: And he shall destroy the wicked, and the sinners together: and they that have forsaken the Lord, shall be consumed.
1.29: For they shall be confounded for the idols, to which they have sacrificed: and you shall be ashamed of the gardens which you had chosen.
1.30: When you shall be as an oak with the leaves falling off, and as a garden without water.
1.31: And your strength shall be as the ashes of tow, and your work as a spark: and both shall burn together, and there shall be none to quench it.

2.1: The word that Isaias, the son of Amos, saw, concerning Juda and Jerusalem.
2.2: *And in the last days the mountain of the house of the Lord shall be prepared on the top of mountains, and it shall be exalted above the hills, and all nations shall flow unto it.
2.3: And many people shall go, and say: Come, and let us go up to the mountain of the Lord, and to the house of the God of Jacob, and he will teach us his ways, and we will walk in his paths: for the law shall come forth from Sion, and the word of the Lord from Jerusalem.
